newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-CELTIC CRASH TO HOME DEFEAT.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-CELTIC CRASH TO HOME DEFEAT.

text.p: Celtic's disastrous start to the season continued at home on Saturday as they crashed to a 2-1 Scottish premier division defeat to Dunfermline.

Newly-promoted St Johnstone are the early table-toppers after winning 1-0 at Motherwell while the day's only other game saw Hearts beat Aberdeen 4-1. Dundee United play Hibs on Sunday while Rangers' game against Kilmarnock was postponed because of international calls.

Celtic, desperate to prevent Rangers eclipsing their record of nine successive titles, began the season with a 2-1 defeat at Hibernian last week and followed up by losing 2-1 to Austria Tirol in the UEFA Cup in midweek.
Things looked to be improving on Saturday when they went ahead in the 40th minute with an Andreas Thom penalty after Henrik Larsson was fouled by Hamish French.
But the lead lasted just a minute into the second half before David Bingham equalised.
And French fully made amends for his misdemeanour 13 minutes from time by hitting the winner from the spot after Malky Mackay had felled Allan Moore in the box.
The result left Celtic bottom of the premier division and Rangers' pre-season odds of 1-6 to win their 10th successive title are already looking generous.
"We always felt pretty confident we could get a result here," said Dunfermline coach Bert Paton.
"It's a new-look Celtic side and we didn't really know what to expect but I think that worked in our favour as it can take some time for a new side to settle down.
"We've got some quality players and in the second half they showed that and I can't praise them highly enough," Paton added.
Hearts hit three goals in six minutes to come from behind and beat Aberdeen at Tynecastle.
Aberdeen went ahead through Mike Newell after 12 minutes but Hearts turned the game round before half time.
A John Robertson penalty levelled the match in the 36th minute, Steve Fulton made it 2-1 two minutes later and Colin Cameron got the third after a further four minutes.
Thomas Flogel completed the rout in the last minute.
Roddy Grant scored the only goal at Motherwell after 65 minutes to put St Johnstone top of the league with four points from two games.
